body: cc @tillrohrmann @twalthr
@tillrohrmann so i am here again and do the rebase. please review when you are free, thanks!
@fhueske , I would like to support minus/minus All after this issue, would you give some suggestion  about this issue?

@eliaslevy with the current implementation we assign the max timestamp to the elements in the IntervalJoin, which means we don't need to delay watermarks. Of course we need to add this in the future when adding the option to use different behaviour

@glaksh100 let me know if you would have time to address my comments. I would like to merge your recent Kinesis changes by the end of this week to be in time for RC1 for 1.6.0. If you don't have the time to address them, I can also close up the loose ends myself while merging.

@StephanEwen I do a rework to minimize changes this PR needs. now there is nothing add to the constructor except a synchronized block(which save us from data race). I think it is clearly JUST parallelize the building process of ExecutionJobVertex, so ask you for review. Thanks.
FYI, there is a work to parallelize the creation of InputSplit in process. Since InputSplit vary from instance to instance, I'd like to try to work on `FileInputSplit` at first.
cc @zentol can you review this?
cc @suez1224 and @twalthr
Looks like splitting on `:` was intentional (see #2482).
I'll take a look today.

hi @zentol.  splitting based on : was added to support multiple file paths.
In windows File.pathSepertor= ";" where as in unix its File.pathSepertor= ":". 
The reference you pointed https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/2482 is correct but in that code base the implementation of setDbStoragePaths() is different from current code base. That is the change in API from org.apache.flink.core.fs.Path to java.io.File and the introduction of an extra File.isAbsolute() check.
Due to the above changes in setDbStoragePaths() its not possible to provide the configuration like this-
state.backend.rocksdb.localdir = file:///some/file/path. If I'm not wrong this is valid way of providing config.
@NicoK here we go 🙌

I'm well aware that `:` was explicitly introduced to support multiple file paths, my point is that it (in hindsight) wasn't a good choice, as other delimiter options exist (`,|;`) that are less ambiguous.
Naturally the alternative is to update the `FileSystem` docs and update the linked test to catch all exceptions.
yes that would be my suggestion.
Note that this of course could break setups where people actually use `:` as a separator :/

@zentol Could you assign this bug to me. 
So there are few more changes that can be done, such as 
1. enhancing the throw statement with appropriate error message along with the file path so the error becomes evident.
I would suggest not to remove File.pathSeperator as it would deny a functionality for user. Moreover File.pathSeperator is an accepted way of providing multiple file paths. Since the key state.backend.rocksdb.localdir expects only local file paths what is the harm in checking for "file".
Thanks for your contribution! Change looks good to me.

just out of curiosity (and I don't know the details there):
Does this still work with the gnu versions of these tools installed, e.g. via `homebrew`? Because at the moment, this completely depends on the OS detection, not on the actual tools.

According to [1]`ifconfig` is not part of coreutils, but more like "a wrapper to the IPConfiguration agent"[2]. IDK if there is any other version of ifconfig out there that could be installed on MacOS, but if it were it would possibly break the code.. I'd say the risk of that happening is rather slim though

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_GNU_Core_Utilities_commands
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ifconfig

The character `:` is actually the standard UNIX path separator. Not supporting this would be kind of strange and break existing setups. We should retain that.

Having simply not URIs with scheme in the config, but only the scheme, does that work?
This works fine state.backend.rocksdb.localdir = /some/file/path. At least there is no (relative path)exception thrown if we give the config in the above mentioned way.

I would suggest to first drive a discussion about what the interface for the creation of input splits would be. The implementation follows that interface.

Design before implementation is always a good idea, before such efforts.

@tzulitai Thanks for reviewing and apologies for the delay. I have addressed all the comments.
I verified the most recent changes with a Flink job reading from a back-logged Kinesis stream and writing to a no-op sink. 
- Number of Kinesis shards - 512
- GetRecord I/O achieved ~= 1.04 Gb/sec
- [numberOfAggregatedRecordsPerFetch](https://github.com/apache/flink/pull/6409) ~= `maxNumberOfRecordsPerFetch`
 
Let me know if it looks alright!
+1 from my side. LGTM.

@tzulitai it would be great if you could merge this PR. We also need it for 
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-4582

+1, thanks for the work @glaksh100 and @tweise for the help on the reviews.
Merging this to master and 1.6 ..

Thanks all for the PR and reviews.
+1, merging this ..

Yes, probably you are right that we should be able to replace it with Slf4jReporter. I had a wrong impression that you need to manually specify which metrics you want to dump. But lets investigate it as separate ticket in the future.

Merging to master.
@GJL Thanks for the review. It's ok for you to take over it.
Hi @fhueske, I wonder if you could take a look at this PR when it's convenient for you. Thanks.
@buptljy conflicts, please update and rebase this PR~
It's just kind of misleading, I was tried to correlate the keyselector with the input stream, which didn't mean two selectors always be different. Never mind, it's not a big deal.
@yanghua fix.
@twalthr I've addressed your latest comments. Could you have another pass?
You mean without checking what the `rollingPolicy` says?

Because this will close the previous AND open a new part file, meaning all buckets, active and inactive, will always be in state. Which we do not want. Also, it means that a bucket that has specified a `rollingInterval` will have a lot of empty part files, as they will open, receive no elements, close due to timeout, and open the next one.

@StephanEwen agree with "design before implementation".

However, the interface for the creation of input splits is definitely `InputSplitSource#createInputSplits`, whose implementations varies from `FileInputFormat` to `JDBCInputFormat` and so on.

Since we need to decide how to create input split in a specific input source, the parallelize logic is various inside the implementation, so implement the parallelize logic case by case if possible and necessary.

I still comment here about this because it is clear to me that the interface for the creation of input splits is definitely `InputSplitSource#createInputSplits` existing.
If you want to share work-in-progress with another committer please just send him the branch directly.

Thanks for the PR @Xpray. For future PRs could you name them `[FLINK-XXXX] [table] Issue title`. This makes it easier for committers to search in the long list of PRs for table-related ones.

@zentol  OK, hold on. 
The problem came from a user on the mailing list who asked questions about the Python DataStream API. Later, I found out that PythonStreamExecutionEnvironment is missing a lot of exposure from the StreamExecutionEnvironment method. I suggest that we can create a JIRA Task to complete the Python API, and then each API can be classified as its child task. What do you think?
@glaksh100 what's the status of this PR? As Chesnay mentioned, we need to document connector metrics.
If you're suggesting something like FLINK-1926 for streaming, sure, go ahead.
@zentol this PR's test will be done in [issue-10024](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLINK-10024) and depends a test class added in PR: #6475
please open a separate PR for the refactoring. A 400 line diff does not qualify as a hotfix.
@zentol rebased and added system resource metrics both to job manager and task manager.
I can open a JIRA and attach the `[hotfix]` to a proper JIRA issue, but it does not make sense to open a new PR and they depend on each other.
then please extend the description of the PR to also cover the refactoring.
Done.
